snippet.textDisplay:
You should have and maintain a constant preparedness kit. The best way to do that is to buy 1 extra of the basic dry and canned goods that you use every time you buy them for 6-12 months depending on their shelf life then after that period rotate your stock forward each time you completely use one of something. The reason you do not buy in a chunk is because you do not want the entire stock to be a part of the same production run or have the same expiration date.


Basic survival preparedness for natural disaster, outbreak, or general civil unrest can and will save save your life.
snippet.textOriginal:
You should have and maintain a constant preparedness kit. The best way to do that is to buy 1 extra of the basic dry and canned goods that you use every time you buy them for 6-12 months depending on their shelf life then after that period rotate your stock forward each time you completely use one of something. The reason you do not buy in a chunk is because you do not want the entire stock to be a part of the same production run or have the same expiration date.


Basic survival preparedness for natural disaster, outbreak, or general civil unrest can and will save save your life.

snippet.textDisplay: This is all ignoring the fact that the number of cases and point of overwhelming medical resources is directly related to the number of people with severe/critical illness. There is variation in symptoms and risk factors. There is also the possibility of herd immunity playing a part in changing the numbers/curve. SARS CoV2 is not likely to just 'disappear'. By isolating everyone at the same time, we are quite possibly just delaying the peak rather than flattening the curve.
snippet.textOriginal: This is all ignoring the fact that the number of cases and point of overwhelming medical resources is directly related to the number of people with severe/critical illness. There is variation in symptoms and risk factors. There is also the possibility of herd immunity playing a part in changing the numbers/curve. SARS CoV2 is not likely to just 'disappear'. By isolating everyone at the same time, we are quite possibly just delaying the peak rather than flattening the curve.

snippet.textDisplay: What I don't understand about this curves is how we can conclude the total amount of cases including recoveries from them? like Grant Sanderson explained on his videos, they don't give us the total number of cases, only the current number of cases, for example if x number of people have recovered and y people have become ill, the curve will grow by y - x, losing the information of how many people have recovered and how many have become infected.

The Lilly pads won't go away, the pandemic will. Bad comparison.

The rapid growth chart shows the end of the epidemic before the gradual chart hits the peak. For the absolute vast majority of us the end of this is far more important than the marginally different severity.

snippet.textDisplay:
I live in Daegu, South Korea, where the country had its first outbreak. EVERYONE wears masks here. EVERYONE. I think that’s one of the big differences with Italy, Iran, and Korea. We all wear masks here. My mom and I wear gloves, as well. Masks help protect the uninfected and help prevent the infected from spreading the virus. When someone who’s not wearing a mask sneezes or spits a little when talking, those droplets are suspended in the air for 30 minutes. Let’s say another person walks into that area within those 30 minutes and is also not wearing a mask, then they breathe in those droplets.

I think the US needs to manufacture and distribute masks asap. Yeah, social distancing helps, but what happens when you’re grocery shopping? People are in and out of supermarkets all the time, I can’t imagine how many droplets are in the air from all those people. Masks, man. Masks.
snippet.textOriginal:
I live in Daegu, South Korea, where the country had its first outbreak. EVERYONE wears masks here. EVERYONE. I think that’s one of the big differences with Italy, Iran, and Korea. We all wear masks here. My mom and I wear gloves, as well. Masks help protect the uninfected and help prevent the infected from spreading the virus. When someone who’s not wearing a mask sneezes or spits a little when talking, those droplets are suspended in the air for 30 minutes. Let’s say another person walks into that area within those 30 minutes and is also not wearing a mask, then they breathe in those droplets.

I think the US needs to manufacture and distribute masks asap. Yeah, social distancing helps, but what happens when you’re grocery shopping? People are in and out of supermarkets all the time, I can’t imagine how many droplets are in the air from all those people. Masks, man. Masks.

snippet.textDisplay:
I feel like people look at this graph, and they forget, that:
A) the capacity of healthcare system is not a flat line. It actually goes down as the medical staff starts getting ill. Eventually if all ambulance crews are in quarantine (even if not all of them are ill!!) the ambulances stop working, cause there is no one to drive and help transport to the hospital
B) there exists a straigh, vertical line. It represents the capacity of the state /society / economy to withstand quarantine. After all if a large part of the workforce cannot work, or is limited in what they can do, then eventually people do not have money to buy essentials, and those essentials stop getting produced as well, tanking the supply.

And if we hit any line BAD things happen. So, pretty much either way we are in a pickle. Unless we are the lucky ones that can work remotely, in which case stay at home as much as possible. Technically you can even avoid shopping for groceries if you have them delivered.
snippet.textOriginal:

A) the capacity of healthcare system is not a flat line. It actually goes down as the medical staff starts getting ill. Eventually if all ambulance crews are in quarantine (even if not all of them are ill!!) the ambulances stop working, cause there is no one to drive and help transport to the hospital
B) there exists a straigh, vertical line. It represents the capacity of the state /society / economy to withstand quarantine. After all if a large part of the workforce cannot work, or is limited in what they can do, then eventually people do not have money to buy essentials, and those essentials stop getting produced as well, tanking the supply.

And if we hit any line BAD things happen. So, pretty much either way we are in a pickle. Unless we are the lucky ones that can work remotely, in which case stay at home as much as possible. Technically you can even avoid shopping for groceries if you have them delivered.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is video is 100% FALSE!
The longer a virus is allowed to spread, the higher the chance of it mutating into something WORSE!
Instead of all this isolation bullshit, everyone should be living their normal lives to help spread the virus, so that antibodies can be developed and immune systems can be strengthened.
What we are being forced to do right now is giving the virus a chance to become something worse, and then that's when we will see the TRUE epidemic.

snippet.textDisplay:
Give people a virus that's spreading across the world, people they know might get infected too and suddenly, countries go in lock down, people are advised to stay inside and health has become THE top priority. Every one does as they're told out of fear.

But what about the climate crisis? Why can't governments enforce rules that are as strict and immediate as now? Then there's only talk about actions and goals in the far future. But when the virus dies down, airports will open again, companies will continue to produce loads of plastic, people will go to work by car again and farms will continue to deliver tons of meat...

snippet.textDisplay: Actually the rapid onset will mean that there will be greater deaths initially but since the outbreak is shorter in duration the virus will eventually burn itself out but in the lower the curve model the virus NEVER burns itself out. In the reduce the curve model whatever actions, interventions or disruptions will last on orders of magnitude longer and that disruption WILL cause orders of magnitude more deaths than the virus ever could. This is the real math that must be considered. Health Care types are not equipped to make country wide or even worse world wide recommendations they are not morally or intellectually equipped to deal with these types of decisions but Military Leaders are. It pays to be smart but it also pays to not be a lemming.

snippet.textDisplay: 6:45 Call it by its name... the Spanish Flu! There is an effort by the PC woke scolds (and little mini war by marxists on wikipedia currently) to try to rewrite history for politcal reasons. For 100 years it was called the Spanish Flu, for it was the Spanish that were the only ones that were willing to inform the public about it. And they should be remembered for being the brave ones for doing so. Yes, it probably originated somewhere else (even the US), but that is the point when bringing up the name, it exposes the story / truth that it wasn't actually from Spain and that it was other governments hiddening it from the public! Currently we have a government in east asia that is trying to supress information about its origins, and the censorship culture warriors that are trying to do the same thing. Hiding the truth of the origin by changing the name of this Wuhan Chinese Virus only hurts us in the end. The perception is that there is something to hide, which is much more scary that this virus.

snippet.textDisplay:
There are two hopes, really. One, that the coming warm weather will end this as any seasonal illness. Two, the vaccine will be available soon for the risk group. Other than that, the slowing is simply not possible. The idea of having enough IC units just doesn't stand calculation.
They say that around 5% of the sick need IC ventilators. In a city of a million, it is 50,000. Now, let's say this city has 500 IC ventilators - which is a good number. Usually not that many. Pushing aside all other patients, those 500 ventilators can serve 12500 corona patients. The curve is, therefore 4 years long. Can we sit at home all this time, and survive financially?
snippet.textOriginal:
There are two hopes, really. One, that the coming warm weather will end this as any seasonal illness. Two, the vaccine will be available soon for the risk group. Other than that, the slowing is simply not possible. The idea of having enough IC units just doesn't stand calculation. 
They say that around 5% of the sick need IC ventilators. In a city of a million, it is 50,000. Now, let's say this city has 500 IC ventilators - which is a good number. Usually not that many. Pushing aside all other patients, those 500 ventilators can serve 12500 corona patients. The curve is, therefore 4 years long. Can we sit at home all this time, and survive financially?

snippet.textDisplay: This whole flattening the curve thing isn't going to work. It will destroy the entire economy. Here in the Netherlands we have around 1700 confirmed cases. Statistics show that 6% of all cases are critical. Hospitals in our province are already stuffed to the brim at the low number of confirmed infections we're at now. The predictions are 50-70% of the Dutch population  (17 million people) will be infected. With a recovery time of ~2 weeks you would have to stay in lockdown for years. And when you finally drop the lockdown and open the borders, some infected people from other countries that did not take the same precautions will come over and the whole thing starts over again.
snippet.textOriginal: This whole flattening the curve thing isn't going to work. It will destroy the entire economy. Here in the Netherlands we have around 1700 confirmed cases. Statistics show that 6% of all cases are critical. Hospitals in our province are already stuffed to the brim at the low number of confirmed infections we're at now. The predictions are 50-70% of the Dutch population  (17 million people) will be infected. With a recovery time of ~2 weeks you would have to stay in lockdown for years. And when you finally drop the lockdown and open the borders, some infected people from other countries that did not take the same precautions will come over and the whole thing starts over again.
